title-group.article-title: Stability analysis and optimization of open pit mine slopes based on the improved Sarma method with nonhomogeneous hydraulic boundary conditions

contrib-group.aff: 1https://ror.org/02egmk993grid.69775.3a0000 0004 0369 0705School of Resources and Safety Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, 100083 China

abstract.p: Although the traditional Sarma method considers the hydrostatic pressure effect, in the actual engineering, the hydraulic conditions are complex and most of them are nonhomogeneous hydraulic boundary conditions, this paper considers the nonhomogeneous hydraulic boundary conditions based on the traditional Sarma method, and based on the improved Sarma method model, the stability evaluation of the designed slope and the slope angle is carried out with the slope of the Aynak open-pit copper mine as the engineering background—optimization study. Firstly, the numerical simulation method carried out the stability analysis of the designed excavation slopes. Then the stability of the final boundary slopes was evaluated based on the improved Sarma method model. The optimization of the final boundary slope angle was carried out by combining the traditional classical limit equilibrium theory and the improved Sarma method model under the conclusion that the originally designed slopes were more stable. The optimal slope angle suitable for the actual working conditions was obtained.

funding-source.institution: Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Slope stability study is a crucial technical problem in open pit mine engineering1,2. In the production process of open pit mines, a large amount of rock and soil excavation leads to the formation of open pit slopes, the stability of which is directly related to the safe operation and economic benefits of the mine. Slope destabilization will not only cause the loss of mining equipment and personnel but also lead to serious environmental disasters. Therefore, scientific research on slope stability is of great practical significance. On the other hand, the size of the slope angle directly affects the mining range, stripping volume, and final economic benefits of the mine3,4. Under the premise of ensuring slope stability, optimizing the slope angle can maximize the utilization rate of mining resources, reduce the amount of unnecessary stripping works, and lower the production cost.

Limit equilibrium method is the most important and commonly used method for slope stability analysis, which first assumes the possible slip surface and the slope is in limit equilibrium, then divides the slope into rigid blocks with vertical boundaries, and then calculates the factor of safety of the whole slope by analyzing the static equilibrium conditions of each block. It was first proposed by the Swedish scholar Peterson in 1915, and later many scholars, such as Fellenius5, Bishop6, Janbu7, Morgenstern and Price8,9, and Spencer10, were devoted to the improvement of the slice method. In addition, with the improvement of computational power, many new methods and advances in slope stability analysis have emerged. For example, numerical simulation techniques such as the finite element strength reduction method have been widely used for slope stability assessment11,12, and compared with the traditional rigid-body limit equilibrium method, the finite element method is able to consider the nonlinear stress-strain characteristics of the soil body and the initial stresses and other factors, and the simulation of complex conditions is more refined13. Studies have shown that the slope safety coefficients obtained by the finite element method are often highly consistent with or even more reliable than the results of the limit equilibrium method14. Sarma’s method is a limit equilibrium analysis method applicable to slip surfaces of arbitrary shape, which accounts for critical seismic acceleration15. Research on the Sarma method continues to deepen in recent years. Zhou et al.16 proposed an improved Sarma method applicable to layered soils to better consider the influence of soil structure on slope stability. Lin Zhiping et al.17 analyzed the impact of inter-slice force distribution on the safety factor calculated by the Sarma method, further refining its mechanical assumptions. Additionally, Shou et al.18 developed a three-dimensional Sarma method, using longitudinal vertical slices for 3D stability analysis of rock slopes, and verified its feasibility through case studies. However, the Sarma method’s simplification of assuming identical hydraulic boundary conditions for the first and last slices contradicts reality. The hydraulic boundary conditions of most engineering slopes are highly complex and often nonhomogeneous. To address this issue, He Manchao et al.19 proposed an improved Sarma method based on nonhomogeneous hydraulic boundary conditions induced by water level fluctuations, referred to as the MSARMA method. Subsequently, numerous scholars have applied and validated the reliability and effectiveness of this method in engineering practice20–23.

In this study, based on the improved Sarma method model with the considered nonhomogeneous hydraulic boundary conditions, we combine several methods to calculate and evaluate the stability of the slope of the Aynak copper mine and propose the optimization method of the slope angle of this slope. Firstly, based on the comprehensive analysis of the geomechanical information of Aynak copper mine, the stability of the designed excavation slope is studied by numerical simulation method, and the stability evaluation of the originally designed slope is carried out based on the improved Sarma method model, on this basis, the slope angle optimization is further carried out by using the classical limit equilibrium theory and the optimized slope angle is verified and analyzed by using the improved Sarma method model. The research results can not only guide the design and production of Aynak copper mine but also provide better examples and research ideas for similar high and steep slope stability analysis research.

sec.title: Improved Sarma method with nonhomogeneous hydraulic boundary conditions
Sarma method mechanical modelling
sec.p: Sarma method is a limit equilibrium method for analysing the stability of slopes and was introduced by Sarma in 197315.The basic idea is that the rock and soil mass of a slope has to be broken into a number of blocks sliding relative to each other, i.e., shear occurs inside the sliding mass, before it can slide, which requires that the analysis satisfies both force and moment equilibria. The mechanical model of the Sarma method divides the soil above the potential sliding surface through the cutting surface into a number of strips, each of which must satisfy the static and moment equilibrium conditions. The method derives an expression for the critical acceleration coefficient by establishing the static equilibrium equations for the strips, incorporating the interaction forces between the strips and the shear strength on the sliding surface. In turn, the factor of safety of the slope is calculated based on the given seismic load or acceleration. The Sarma method is characterised by its ability to deal with sliding surfaces of arbitrary shapes, including non-circular shapes, and by its ability to analyse the effect of seismic action on slope stability.

caption.p: Force analysis of Sarma method bar block.

sec.title: Improved Sarma method with nonhomogeneous hydraulic boundary conditions

caption.p: Schematic of various hydraulic boundaries (a) Boundary condition (b) Boundary condition 2 (c) Boundary condition 3 (d) Boundary condition 4.

sec.p: Assuming that the slope can be divided into n blocks, in Fig. 2a, the boundary force on the left side of the first block and the right side of the n-th block is 0, that is, both E1 and En+1 are 0, which is the boundary condition of the traditional Sarma method. Under this condition, the dynamic load acceleration coefficient Kc is calculated by Eq. (8).

In Fig. 2b, the force on the left boundary of the first block is 0, which is a homogeneous hydraulic boundary condition. The right boundary of the n-th block is subjected to hydrostatic pressure, which is a non-homogeneous hydraulic boundary condition, and the boundary condition at this time is Eq. (9); the corresponding dynamic load acceleration coefficient Kc calculation equation is Eq. (10) :

In Fig. 2c, the left boundary of the first block is subjected to hydrostatic pressure, which is a non-homogeneous hydraulic boundary condition; the force on the right boundary of the n-th block is 0, which is the homogeneous hydraulic boundary condition, and the boundary condition at this time is Eq. (11); the corresponding dynamic load acceleration coefficient Kc calculation formula is Eq. (12) :

In Fig. 2d, the left boundary of the first block and the right boundary of the n-th block are both subjected to hydrostatic pressure, which is a non-homogeneous hydraulic boundary condition; the boundary condition at this time is Eq. (13); the corresponding dynamic load acceleration coefficient Kc calculation formula is Eq. (14) :

sec.title: Engineering situations
Location and physical geography
sec.p: Aynak copper mine is located about 49 km southeast of Kabul, the capital city of Afghanistan (Fig. 3), under the jurisdiction of Logar Province. The central geographic coordinates of the mine area: 34º16′ N latitude, 69º18′ E longitude, located in the east-central part of the Afghanistan Plateau, on the north-west side of the Aynak mountain range, adjacent to the Logar River floodplain, belonging to the plateau hilly landscape, with high terrain and large undulations, with an elevation of the mine area ranging from 2,275 to 2,750 m above sea level.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the location of the mine. Map generated using Google Earth (version 10.85.0.1., https://earth.google.com/web/search/Aynak+Copper+Mining+Area,+Afghanistan).

sec.title: Mining geology
Stratigraphic lithology
sec.p: The stratigraphy of the Aynak copper mine area ranges from old to new, including the Proterozoic bedrock, Tertiary, and Quaternary. The Quaternary and Upper Tertiary are unconformably contacted overlying Precambrian old strata. The Quaternary are mainly residual and alluvial layers. Due to its late formation, the Upper Tertiary consists of loose, semi-consolidated, and consolidated siltstones, fine sandstones, coarse sandstones, and gravel-sand layer. In contrast, the Precambrian strata consist of metamorphic rock series of the Middle-Lower Proterozoic and Upper Proterozoic, where the Middle-Lower Proterozoic contain the Sheldawaz Formation (Pt1–2sh) and the Kroger Formation (Pt1–2kr), which have not been found distributed on the surface within the mining area, the Upper Paleoproterozoic is composed of the Vileya Formation (Pt3vl), the Loykhvar Formation (Pt3lh), and the Gurihamid Formation (Pt3gl), with the Loykhvar Formation (Pt3lh) being the ore-forming horizon of the Aynak copper mine.

sec.title: Geological structure
sec.p: The Aynak copper mine consists of the lower, middle, and upper structural layers from the bottom up. The lower structural layer is a metasedimentary “geosyncline tectonic unit” composed of amphibolite and crystalline schist of the Kroger Formation and Sheldawaz Formation of the Middle and Lower Proterozoic, and amphibolite and crystalline schist of the Vilayaki Formation of the Upper Proterozoic, which contains marble and quartzite. The lower structural layer is a north-east oriented short-axis anticlinal fold in the mining area, which is in contact with the middle structural layer as an unconformity or fault. The total thickness of the lower structural layer is about 7,000 m. The middle structural layer is the Upper Proterozoic Loykhvar Formation land-sourced offshore carbonate layer, covered by the Guri Hamid Volcano mafic rock body, the “platform tectonic unit”. The upper structural layer is the upper Tertiary sedimentary layer of the Cenozoic era, which is in the form of a nearly horizontal thick layer directly overlying the middle and lower structural layers. In the eastern part of the western mining area and the eastern part of the central mining area, the upper Tertiary overburden is thicker, with a thickness of more than 4,000 m, and is in unconformable contact with the middle structural layer.

sec.title: Mechanical parameters of engineering rock mass
sec.p: To comprehensively grasp the physical and mechanical characteristics of the lithology of each stratum in the mining area, and at the same time to provide basic data for the stability analysis of open-pit slopes and mining design parameters, indoor rock mechanics tests, including uniaxial compression tests, triaxial compression tests, and split tests, were carried out on the lithologies involved in the stratum of the mining area, and the parameters such as density, elastic modulus, Poisson ratio, cohesion, angle of internal friction, and tensile strength were obtained for the main stratum of the lithology in the mining area. In addition, based on the field fissure survey and rock mass quality classification, the shear strength parameters, deformation parameter, and tensile strength index of the engineered rock mass were calculated by Hoek-Brown correction algorithm based on GSI method with strong applicability, and the finalized mechanical parameters of the rock mass were as shown in Table 1, which provide reliable basic data for the subsequent calculation of slope stability. The calculated mechanical parameters of engineering rock mass provide reliable basic data for the subsequent slope stability calculation.

caption.p: Mechanical parameters of engineering rock mass.

sec.title: Numerical simulation analysis of design slope excavation stability
sec.p: Numerical simulation analysis was carried out using Flac3D software for the typical profile of designed excavation slope according to different stages. The selected profile is located in the southeast part of the quarry, with a slope inclination of 116°. Since the upper part of the slope is Tertiary soft rock and the lower part is Gurihamid Formation bedrock, the design scheme takes into account the differences in the physical and mechanical properties of these two types of rock bodies and selects different slope angles for the upper Tertiary soft rock and the lower Gurihamid Formation bedrock. In the original design scheme, the slope angle of the upper Tertiary soft rock is 36°, and the slope angle of the lower Gurihamid Formation bedrock is 43°, so this study optimizes the upper Tertiary soft rock and the lower bedrock respectively. The Tertiary cover is thick, ranging from 200 m to 300 m in thickness, and the main lithologies are siltstone, sandy-mudstone, Medium-Fine sandstone, marl, gravel-sand layer, and conglomerate, and the Tertiary rock layers are distributed approximately horizontally. The representative lithologies of hard rock are amphibolite and carbonaceous quartz schist, and the hard rock formations are distributed in an anticlinal manner with open slopes. Geological tectonics in the region is strong, there are two large fault crushing zones through, the fault strike is about NE60 °, the dip is more than 75 °, nearly perpendicular to the ground surface downward extension of five to six hundred meters, and faults on both sides of the extension of the small crushing zones, resulting in the fragmentation of the rock body, joints, and fissures developed. The calculations were performed using an ideal elastic-plastic model, and the Mohr-Coulomb yield criterion was used to determine the damage of the rock mass, with the boundary conditions as follows: the upper surface was set as a free boundary, the bottom was restricted to the horizontal and vertical displacements, and the two side faces were restricted to the horizontal displacements. The computational profile is shown in Fig. 4, and the simulation process is as follows: before excavation, the model is consolidated to form the initial stress field; then the model is excavated in three phases to analyze the stability of the slope in the natural state, and the selected mechanical parameters of the rock body are shown in Table 1, and the mechanical parameters of the fault are shown in Table 2.

sec.title: Analysis of displacement field calculation results
sec.p: Figure 5 shows the displacement cloud diagram of the designed slope at different excavation stages, with the increase of excavation depth, the maximum displacement of the slope as a whole gradually increases, the maximum displacement is 14.7 cm when the excavation reaches 520 m, the displacement is larger at the bottom of the slope and the slope face, and the direction of the displacement field at the bottom of the slope and at the slope face is pointing to the free surface. The reason is the upward rebound caused by the excavation, and the closer to the bottom and face of the slope, the larger the rebound displacement. At the junction of Tertiary and marl, the displacement of the slope is larger. The maximum displacement occurs at the junction of the left fault and the slope. The reason may be that the lithology of the rock layer here is poor, and the excavation has disturbed the rock layer at the fault, producing a large displacement.

caption.p: Design excavation slope displacement cloud diagram (a) Stage 1: excavation 120 m (b) Stage 2: excavation 315 m (c) Stage 3: excavation 520 m.

sec.title: Analysis of stress field calculation results
sec.p: Figure 6a shows the cloud diagram of shear stress in different excavation stages of the designed slope, when excavating the pebble soil of the Quaternary and part of the rock and soil body of the Tertiary, only in the vicinity of the fault, a relatively obvious larger shear stress appeared; in the bedrock part of the lower part of the slope, a stress concentration phenomenon appeared. Figure 6b shows the maximum principal stress cloud diagrams of different excavation stages of the designed slope. The principal stresses are distributed in layers with the increase of depth, almost parallel to each other with the slope surface, and seldom appear sudden changes, and there is only a small amount of stress concentration phenomenon in the rock stratum division of the lithosphere and near the fault; with the excavation of the rock body, the principal stresses on the upper slope surface gradually become larger, and in the bedrock rock stratum, the principal stresses on the slope surface are smaller than those on the Tertiary and Quaternary rock stratum. principal stresses at the slope face.

caption.p: Stress cloud diagram of design excavation slope (a) Shear stress cloud diagram (b) Maximum principal stress cloud diagram.

sec.title: Plastic zone distribution
sec.p: Figure 7 shows the distribution of plastic zone in different excavation stages of the designed slope, local tensile damage occurs at the slope face, top and foot of the slope, the reason is mainly due to its geological factors, the tensile damage at the top of the slope, on the one hand, is due to the proximity of the fault, on the other hand, the surface is the Quaternary pebble soil with low tensile strength, which leads to the local tensile damage due to the release of the stress while the fault is disturbed in the process of the excavation; At the early stage of excavation, due to the release of stress, at the same time, because of the low tensile strength of the Tertiary geotechnical soil, it will produce tensile damage at the bottom of the slope; the damage of the slope surface in the Tertiary of the rock layer is obvious, most of them are tensile damage, which is very related to the geotechnical nature of the Tertiary of the rock layer, and due to the Tertiary and the bedrock at the junction of the fault is adjacent to the junction, therefore, there is a composite type of damage of tensile and shear in this place.

caption.p: Distribution of plastic zones of design excavation slopes (a) Stage 1: excavation 120 m (b) Stage 2: excavation 315 m (c) Stage 3: excavation 520 m.

sec.title: Stability analysis of final realm slope improved Sarma method and slope angle optimization
Stability evaluation of original design slope angle
sec.p: Based on the theory of improved Sarma method with nonhomogeneous hydraulic boundary conditions, the computer program “Slope Stability Evaluation Design System” was prepared, and the slope stability coefficient calculation was carried out with the help of this software, combined with the relevant norms and relevant engineering examples to consider, the slope stability safety coefficient Fs =1.2 was selected as the security reserve factor in this study, and based on the surface exposure characteristics of the structural surface obtained from the borehole data and the site investigation, different dangerous surfaces locations were identified, and based on the different slip surface locations, a slope calculation model was established, as shown in Fig. 8.

When calculating, the seismic intensity of the area is considered to be VIII degree, the value of seismic acceleration is 0.2 g, the slope drainage rate is considered to be 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100%, and the most unfavorable state is assumed to be the saturated state, and the mechanical parameters of the rock body adopted in the calculation are shown in Table 1, and a geomechanical model is established for each potentially dangerous surfaces respectively as shown in Fig. 9, and the results of the stabilization coefficients calculation are shown in Table 3.

caption.p: Computational mechanics model of potentially dangerous surfaces (a) Dangerous surfaces 1 (b) Dangerous surfaces 2 (c) Dangerous surfaces 3.

sec.p: According to the calculation results of the stability coefficient of the original design slope, with the increase of the drainage rate, the slope safety coefficient increases gradually; for different potentially dangerous surfaces, the overall safety coefficient is Dangerous Surfaces 1 > Dangerous Surfaces 2 > Dangerous Surfaces 3 in order of magnitude, in which the safety coefficient of Dangerous Surfaces 3 under the condition of natural drainage rate is 0% is 1.24, which indicates that the slope is stable under the condition of no drainage and seismic force, and can be further optimized from the economic point of view. It shows that the slope is stable under the condition of no drainage and seismic force, and the slope angle can be optimized from an economic point of view.

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis of factors affecting the stability of the original design slope
sec.p: Using the sensitivity analysis function in “Slope Stability Evaluation and Design System”, the sensitivity analysis of several important factors affecting the stability of the slope is carried out, including the gravity γ, the cohesive of the bottom slip surface Cb, and angle of internal friction of the bottom sliding surface φb, cohesion of side sliding surface Cs and angle of internal friction side sliding surface φs, and the seismic coefficient Kc, and the analysis curves are shown in Fig. 10.

caption.p: Slope sensitivity analysis (a) Gravity γ (b) Seismic coefficient Kc (c) Cohesion of the bottom slip surface Cb (d) Angle of internal friction of the bottom sliding surface φb (e) Cohesion of side sliding surface Cs (f) Angle of internal friction of side sliding surface φs.

sec.p: From the results of sensitivity analysis, it can be seen that the slope rock mass gravity γ, seismic coefficient Kc, the value of angle of internal friction of bottom sliding φb of the bottom slip surface, and the value of angle of internal friction side sliding surface φs of the side slip surface are the factors that have the greatest influence on the steady state of slopes, and they are the main reasons for inducing deformation and damage of slopes. With the increase of gravity, the slope safety coefficient increases, in the case of complete non-drainage of the slope, if the gravity of the slope rock mass increases from 15 kN/m3 to 35 kN/m3, its safety coefficient will increase by 0.12, and its influence on the slope safety coefficient is the largest when the gravity is from 15 kN/m3 to 25 kN/m3; with the increase of the seismic coefficient, the safety coefficient of the slope decreases gradually, and the smaller seismic coefficient. At the same time, different slope drainage rates in different seismic coefficients have different impacts on slope stability, especially when the drainage rate is 25%, 50% and 75%, the difference is most obvious; slope safety coefficient increases with the increase of the angle of internal friction of bottom sliding, but in the small angle of internal friction of bottom sliding (< 20°), the change of the drainage rate of the slope has less influence on the slope stability, and with the increase of the angle of internal friction of bottom sliding, the influence of the change of the drainage rate on the slope safety coefficient also increases; Similarly, the slope safety coefficient increases with the increase of the angle of internal friction side sliding surface, and its effect on the slope safety coefficient varies with different drainage rates, but the cohesive of the bottom slip surface does not have a great effect on the slope safety coefficient, and its safety coefficient only increases by about 0.01 when the cohesive of the bottom slip surface is increased from 0 to 100 kPa, and similarly, with the increase of the cohesion of side sliding surface, the slope coefficient of safety hardly changes.

sec.title: Optimization of final realm slope angle
sec.p: After the above calculation, the slope safety coefficient of the profile is more than 1.2, in a stable state and still has a large safety redundancy, from the economic point of view, to more efficiently exploit the mineral resources, reduce the amount of invalid stripping and avoid the waste of resources, improve the utilization rate of the resources, and reduce the cost of mining, the angle of the side slopes is further optimized. Firstly, the slope stability of the upper and lower parts of the slope is calculated and analyzed by using the Geo-SLOPE software, and then it is calculated by using the Improved Sarma Method, which is compared with other classical limit equilibrium theory calculations to verify the results, and the rock mechanical parameters used in the calculation are shown in Table 1.

sec.title: Classical limit equilibrium theory slope angle optimization
sec.p: The original design scheme is that the slope angle of the upper Tertiary soft rock is 36°, and the slope angle of the lower Gurihamid Formation bedrock is 43°. The SLOPE/W module in Geoslope software is used to optimize the slope angle of the upper and lower slopes respectively, and the limit equilibrium method used includes the Ordinary method, Bishop method, Janbu method, and Morgenstern-Price method, and the calculation takes into account that the seismic intensity of the area is VIII degree, the seismic acceleration value is 0.2 g, and the calculation is done until the slope stability coefficient is less than the minimum safety factor Fs = 1.2, the results of the calculation of the upper Tertiary soft rock side slope are shown in Fig. 11, and the results of the calculation of the lower Gurihamid Formation bedrock slope are shown in Fig. 12.

caption.p: Factor of safety for upper Tertiary soft rock side slopes (a) Upper Tertiary soft rock side slope angle 36° (b) Upper Tertiary soft rock side slope angle 37° (c) Upper Tertiary soft rock side slope angle 38°.

sec.p: From the calculation results, it can be seen that there are some differences in the results of the limit equilibrium methods due to the differences in the calculation methods. The results of the Ordinary and Janbu methods are relatively small, while the results of Bishop and Morgenstern-Price methods are large.

As can be seen from Fig. 11, the safety coefficient of the upper slope calculated according to the initial design of the initial slope angle of 36° is 1.267, which indicates that the stability of the Tertiary soft rock side slope is better, and the angle of the Tertiary soft rock side slope can be further improved, and after the angle is increased by 1°, the safety coefficient is 1.204, which is still larger than the security reserve factor of 1.2, and after the angle of the slope is further increased by 1° to reach 38°, the safety coefficient is 1.18, which does not meet the minimum safety coefficient requirement, so the optimum slope angle of the upper Tertiary soft rock side slope is initially selected as 37°.

caption.p: Safety factor of lower bedrock slope (a) Lower bedrock slope angle 43° (b) Lower bedrock slope angle 44°.

sec.p: The results of the lower bedrock slope safety coefficient calculation are shown in Fig. 12. In the initial design scheme, the lower slope angle is 43°, and its safety coefficient is 1.207, which meets the requirement of the minimum safety coefficient of 1.2. Further attempts were made to increase the angle of this slope by 1° to 44°, and the calculated safety coefficient is 1.18, which is smaller than the safety coefficient threshold of 1.2, so the optimal slope angle of this slope was initially selected as 43°.

sec.title: Optimization verification of slope angle by improved Sarma method
sec.p: Based on the improved Sarma method model, the optimization validation of the upper Tertiary soft rock side slope and the lower Gurihamid Formation bedrock slope was carried out respectively, and the calculation considered that the seismic intensity of the area was VIII degree, the seismic acceleration value was 0.2 g, and the natural drainage rate of the slope was considered according to 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100%, and the calculation results of the safety coefficient of the upper slope are shown in Fig. 13, and the calculation results of the safety coefficient of the lower slope are shown in Fig. 14.

caption.p: Factor of safety of upper Tertiary soft rock side slopes calculated by improved Sarma method (a) Upper Tertiary soft rock side slope angle 36° (b) Upper Tertiary soft rock side slope angle 37° (c) Upper Tertiary soft rock side slope angle 38°.

sec.p: According to the calculation results in Fig. 13, the slope stability evaluation based on the MSARMA method fully considered parameters such as lithology, borehole information, stratigraphic yield, slope yield, seismic load, groundwater, and slope geometry. The slope safety coefficient increases with the increase of the natural drainage rate, which indicates that the slope becomes less stable under the influence of water, and the stability is the worst in the state of no drainage at all. The factor of safety for the most dangerous surfaces of the upper Tertiary soft rock 37° optimized slopes is Fs = 1.2358 for the undrained condition and Fs = 1.2954 for the fully drained condition. If the Tertiary slopes are designed according to a 37° slope angle, the slopes are in a stable state under completely undrained conditions and seismic forces, with a factor of safety Fs > 1.2; The coefficient of safety for the most dangerous surfaces of the upper Tertiary soft rock 38° optimized slope is Fs = 1.1316 for the undrained condition and Fs = 1.2660 for the fully drained condition. If the Tertiary slope is designed according to the 38° slope angle, the slope is in an unstable state under completely undrained conditions and seismic forces, and the factor of safety Fs < 1.2, so the finalized optimal slope angle for the upper Tertiary soft rock side slope of this slope is 37°.

caption.p: Factor of safety of lower bedrock slopes calculated by improved Sarma’s method (a) Lower bedrock slope angel 43° (b) Lower bedrock slope angel 44°.

sec.p: The coefficient of safety for the most dangerous slip surface of the bedrock slopes of the lower Gurihamid Formation is Fs = 1.2148 for the undrained condition and Fs = 1.2597 for the fully drained condition. If the bedrock slope is designed according to a 43° slope angle, the slope is in a stable condition with a coefficient of safety Fs > 1.2 under completely undrained conditions and seismic forces; If the slope angle is designed according to 44°, the slope will be in an unstable condition with the coefficient of safety Fs < 1.20 under the completely undrained condition and seismic force, so the finalized optimal slope angle for the bedrock slopes of the Gurihamid Formation in the lower part of this slope is 43°.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study addresses the limitations of the traditional Sarma method in handling nonhomogeneous hydraulic boundary conditions. Based on the engineering context of the Aynak open-pit copper mine slope, an improved Sarma method model was established. Integrated with numerical simulation and limit equilibrium theory, the research conducted stability assessment and slope angle optimization. The main conclusions are as follows:

list-item.p: Numerical simulation indicates that excavation unloading causes stress redistribution. Local tensile and shear failures are concentrated at the slope face, slope toe, and lithologic/fault interfaces. While the overall slope stability is good, localized shear-slip risks exist, requiring targeted monitoring.

Using an independently developed analytical system incorporating the improved Sarma method that accounts for nonhomogeneous hydraulic boundary conditions, slip surface models of typical cross-sections were constructed to evaluate the stability of the originally designed slope. The results show that under combined undrained and seismic loading conditions, the safety factors for all potential critical slip surfaces exceed 1.2, indicating room for optimization. Sensitivity analysis further revealed that slope unit weight, seismic coefficient, and shear parameters along slip surfaces have the most significant influence on the safety factor.

Ensuring the safety factor remained not lower than the code-specified threshold, slope angle optimization for the overlying soft rock layer and the underlying bedrock layer was performed using both classical limit equilibrium methods and the improved Sarma model. It was determined that stability requirements are met under varying drainage conditions when the optimized slope angles are ≤ 38° for the upper Tertiary soft rock slope and ≤ 44° for the lower Gulihamid Formation bedrock slope. The results showed high consistency with calculations from multiple limit equilibrium methods, further verifying their reliability.

fn.p: Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The data presented in this study are all already included in the manuscript.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
